summary: On September 26, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana entered a default judgment against Richard N. Bell, a professional photographer, Bigado Networks Inc., MJ Consulting Services, Inc., and EZ Ticket, LLC for copyright infringement.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Indianapolis, alleges that Bell violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Bell has agreed to settle the action by consenting to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders him to pay $150,000 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of $2,000.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Central District of New York today announced criminal charges against Bell.  According to the SEC's Complaint, filed on September 24, 2019 in the Northern District of Illinois, Bell was among the defendants charged in the Carmen case, and the court found that Bell was precluded from relitigating whether he owns a copyright in the skyline photograph when there was no dispute between the potential owners of the photograph and the party in the action.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Bell has consented to a judgment permanently enjoining him from further violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933, and ordering him to disgorge $5,000, which he has already paid to a third party, and pay $7,500 in civil penalties.  He has also agreed to be permanently enjoined from associating with any third party that does not have standing to assert a work made for hire defense against copyright infringement, including, without limitation, the right to reapply as a defendant in a future case.  On September 11, 2018, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Bell, charging him with violating Sections 5 and 5 of the Exchange Act and Rules 5a-11, 13a-13, and 13b-14 thereunder, and with aiding and abetting Bell's violations of Section 13(b)(2) of Exchange Act Rule 13b2-1.  It also charged Bell with violating Exchange Act Section 5 and Rule 12b-20, and seeks a permanent injunction against Bell and other defendants, as well as a penalty against Bell from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney.  Among other things, the court granted Bell's motion for default on all of the charges against him, and ordered him to
